div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,560] ALEXANDRIA, WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 1, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at TOR (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Venice every Wednesday about 8:30 a.m. in time for Express Switzerland, Paris and London leaving Venice 2 p.m. and 11.20 p.m. Arrival Trieste every Wednesday about 3 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9.30 a.m. and are conveyed direcly to Quay alongside steamer.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette The English Daily newspaper, Established 1880. Editor and Manager - R. SMELLING Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF. MONDAY, JULY 30, 1908.
THE RUSSIAN CRISIS-
div.p: The lack of taot which has been the most conspicuous feature of the Tsar's dealings with his people since the reply was given to the first Address of the Duma is shown equally in the Imperial Decree recording its dismissal. 'The representatives of the nation have strayed into spheres beyond their competence," says the Tsar; and the instances oited are three. They have made inquiries into the aots of local authorities instituted by the Emperor, which, being i nterpreted, is, that they have presumed to fix the responsibility of the Bielostok massacres upoo their real authors, md they have complained cf the corruption of the Bureaucracy. Again, they have made com- mentg/on the imperfections of the fundamental iaw», which can only be modified by the Im- perial will. Bit the Russian code is notorioosly both contradictory and barbarous ; and it is mrely not beyond the competence even of a merely deliberative body to suggest the exci­sion of admitted fanlts. Thirdly, they have appealed'to the nation, and this, it is true, was a mistake both in tactics and on higher constitutional ground. Whether it was a orimeb which necessitated the dissolution of the body which committed it we take leave to doubt: but the excuse put forward that the peasants were "disturbed by saoh anomalies" will not hold. They were much more disturbed by the war with Japan, which to many was a revela- 'ion of a new world; and the fact that they had a voice in the affairs of their ooontry at all was a more glaring anomaly than any excess committed by their representatives in St Petersburg. The alternative see-saw between Parliamentary government and the inflexible will of Nioholas II. will beoome a disturbing feature of the first magnitude during the next few months, aid though the peasant's mind I moves slowly, when he has once decided on aotion he does not draw back.

Taken at the best, the situation is moat serioas. Even though we indulge in the almost impossible hope that everything will remain quiet, the next Duma mast be far less concilia­tory in tone than the one whose end has now come, says the "Globe . The moderating infiaenoe of the Constitutional Demoorats will be absent,for, like the Trimmers of old in England, the party of compromise will be rejeoted as men unfit for a crisis. It is inconceivable that either the Court or officialdom will be represented to any extent. The former has alienated all save its immediate circle, and perhaps the lowest class of the bourgeoisie, the smaller shopkeepers, who have ever been its most fanatical sup­porters.* The Bureaucracy are detested from eud to end of the Empire; in this all Rus­sian opinion is at one with the audience which first saw an historio drama dealing with that class at St. Petersburg years ago, and was moved to exolaim, "There is not an honest man among them all." This leaves for members of the next Duma merely the extremists, whose opposition to the Tsar knows no bounds, and the visionaries, whose remedies are made up of a mixture of French philosophy trwo centuries old and a parody of German socialism. It is not to such men that the Mperor can look for the salvation of his country. But before the next election so much may happen that the speculation is unproditblina any event, the Tsar has played his last card, and played it badly. It revolution does not come, he will be face to face witrh a Duma whose demands tiw ill be impossible to concede. If the situation becomes so threatening that he gives way and convokesParliament before the date stated in the Ukase he will be a defeated monarch, and the people will have an anormous advantage on the next rubber. On the other hand, if the revolution can no longer be stayed, he will find the has lost the support of the whole Empire, and even the Army may prove to be a broken reed when he requires its aid the most.

div.head: Assault on European.
div.p: While travelling on a trolley to the quarries behind the Tombs of the Khalifa, Cairo, yes­terday morning, an Italian foreman, belonging to the State Railways, was attacked by natives, who so roughly handled him as to disable him for several days. The trolley pashers did not raise a finger in defence of their master bat looked on all the time.

div.head: Snapshotting Denishwai.
div.p: Sir E. Grey informed Mr. MaoNeill, M.P., in the House of Commons last week, that he had no information as to the circumstances in which certain photographs of the Denshawi hangings and Hoggings were taken and publish­ed All spectators were kept at a considerable distance from the scene of the executions by a cordon of police, with the exception of the members of the Press, who were on the public road. The authorities had no responsibility either for the taking of the photographs or their publication.

div.head: Carlton Extension.
div.p: Mr. C. Aquilina, proprietor of the Carlton Hotel, Bnlkeley, is to be congratulated on the extension which he has just made to his hotel. With the increasing popularity of theCarltoD, both in summer and winter, it became evident that the available accommodation was be­coming too restricted, and so Mr. Aquilina bad a new wing constructed on the side of the hotel facing the Ramleh road. This wing has jnat been opened and increases the hotel accom­modation by 14 bedrooms facing doe Dorth 'tnd exposed to the invigorating sea breezep. 1 hef-e rooms have all been furnished with sxqnieite taste aDd, when it is more widely known that Mr. Aqoilina's inclusive charges are so noderate as P.T. 40 per dsy, they should rot long remain unoccupied. Space has also been found in the new wing of the bnilding for a npacioos and welhdocorated dining room, the former dining-room being converted into a reading room, and there is also a new and comfortable loangO.

div.head: CONSTITUTION FOR THE TRANSVAAL
div.p: GOVERNMENT'S GREAT ERROR
BRITON AND BOER
London, Jaly 31.
House of Comm >ns —The Transvaal Con­stitution ha* been adopted by 315 votes to 8q.

Mr. W. Churchill, exuUinioBr the Constitu­tion, said that the gniding principle in granting responsible government to the Transvaal was to extend to Briton and Boer the fallest priv - leges of British oitizenship. The Government had adopted the principle of manhood suffrage and single members for constituencies. There were to be 34 members f r the Rand, 6 for Pretoria, and 29 fjr the rest of the Transvaal. Dotoh or English was to be spoken. The second Chamber was to be nominated for the duration of the first* Parliament and after that, to be elected.
The Constitution contains a clause abrogat­ing the Chinese ordinance, after a reasonable time, declaring that no 'a * shon'd be assented to which sanctioned servile service or forced residence.
The Hon. Alfred Lyttelton and Mr Ba'fonr
British supremacy, and that the only hopeful featare was the postponement of the granting of responsible government to the Orange R:ver Colony.

Mr. Balfour declined any responsibility for "the most reck'ess experiment in the history of oor colonial policy." "What security," he said, "was there that the powers now conferred on the Transvaal Colony would not. be used to establish a condition of things which would make fatare anti British action probable and dangerous ?"

Sir H. Campbell Bannerman exclaimed that never in the course of h;s parliamentary expo rienoe had he listened to a more unwjrthy mischievous, and unpatriotic speech. This remark called forth a protest from the Opposi­tion and Ministerial cheers.
House of Lords.—Lord Elgin made a state­ment similar to Mr. W. Churchill's.

Lord Milner said that the Government was making a great error, and that it would be absolutely wrong t) follow a oonrse which might, within a year, remit in Generals Bo*ba and Smuts contro'ling the Government of the Transvaal. (Jieuter)

div.head: SERIOUS FIRE IN CAIRO.
div.p: A serious fire occurred on Moaday evening in Cairo in 8haria el Godarieh, in the Darb p) Ahmar district, in an oil and paint store which is situated between the Greek Orthodox church and the Mttwalli mosqne. Very shortly after the fire was discovered the flames apsu- med alarming proportions, and had it not been for the prompt arrival of the Fire Brigade under the command of Captain Blake with three fire engines, the damage must have been far more extensive.

In consequence of the highly ii flammable nature of the oontents of the store and the remote possibility of saving i\ the attention of the brigade was chiefly directed towards the surrounding buildings and, though it was not until tin small hours of the morning that the brigade could leave the seme, all danger of a serioas extension of the fire was averted in a very short space of time.
A considerable portion cf the contents of the stoie were rescued, but the damages, which include the destruction of tw» bui'dings, are estimated at about £ If ,< 00.

div.head: STRIKE OF MUNICIPAL EMPLOYES
div.p: The stonecutters in the service of the Alexandria Mnnicipality, to the nt.mb r of 110, have gone out on strike. They demand less than the tenhonrs day, which has been the habitual duration of their daily work, and also an increase in wages. For the Europeans the pay varies from 4 to 6 francs and for the Arabs from 2 to 3 franc* per diem.

Only two or three men remained at work this morning but the strike will be general this evening. The men oomplain that their life is now intolerable owing to the increase in house rent and the rise in price of food.

div.head: COTTON WORM.
div.p: The operations for the destruction of the cotton worm which were carried on last week met with the same success as in the former weeks. Daring this period no signs of the pest were observed in the provinces of Assioat, Beni Soaef, and Keneb, and the reports from other provinces are as follows :—
Behera — 39,432 feddans, including 254 villages, were infected and cleared.
Sbarkieh—171 feddans,including 10 villages, were infected and cleared.
Dakahlieh—2,331 leddans, including 71 villages, were infected and of these 2,282 feddans were cleared.
Fayoum—2 feddans were infected and cleared.
Gharbieh—2,725 feddans, including 46 villages, were infected, and of these 1,502, feddans were oleared.
Gh'zeh—118 feddans, including 3 villages, were infected, and with the exception of 1 feddan the whole area was cleared.
Kalioabieh—128 feddans, including 19 villages, were infected and cleared,
Menoufieh—440 feddans, including 18 villages, were infected and oleared.
Minieh—39 feddans, including 5 villages,

div.head: MINDEN DAY
div.p: trooping or the colour.

The troo; ing of the colour by the 1st Batta­lion of the Lancashire Fusiliers, in celebration of the great Battle of Minden (which was fought on August 1, 1769), took place at 7 o'clock this morning on Abdeen-square', Cairo.

The main portion of the battalion was drawn up in line in front of the Palace, and facing them, on the opposite side of the square, was a line of Fusiliers and the 4th Battalion Egyptian Infantry. All the officers and men of the Lancashire Fusiliers wore in their hairnets a red and a white or yellow rose. The drums were Ir.jvily decorated with the same tl ,we., and a wreath of red and white roses topped the coloar.

At the commencsment of the ceremony the battalion was inspected by Col. Cuthbert, temporarily in command of the Army of Occu­pation. The ooloars were led out and after the salute were handed to the officer in charge of the escort column. They were trooped roand the square esoorted by the whole battalion, and after reforming in double line the battalion advanced in review order and the ceremony was then oonoluded.
Alter the trooping of the colour, Major Hamilton and the officers of the battalion
considered that no security was afforded fn received their friends in a large marquee
which ha 1 been (rected in the square.

div.head: A PRECEDENT FOR SPECIAL COURTS.
div.p: One seems to have overlooked the fact, says the. Cairo Correspondent of the "Pall Mall Gazette " that once before in the history of the British occupation of Egypt, unconstitu­tional measures had to be taken in order to settle the natives. It was in 1884, when raid* ing and brigandage was oarried on on an pi.ojiu ua scale in the provinces, and bad come to such a pass that the Native Courts were helpless to repress it. The Criminal Code was set aside, and special oourts, under the title of "Commissions of Brigandage," were instituted for the trial of all criminal acts. They were given the power of summary juris- diotion, and their decisions savoured very muoh of oourt-martial law. These Commissions sat for five years, until the arrival in the country of Mr. (afterwards Sir John) Soott, who was destined to become Judioial Adviser.

These special oourts had a great effect on the raids and brigandage, and, so to speak, stamped them oat, hat they, themselves, were g i'ty of great abases. In many cases the innocent suffered for the guilty, and the per­sonal element entered verueften into the oases. The Commissions were composed of natives, presided over by the Madir or Governor of the province. There was no European gaiding spirit, or even a system of inspection. The Commissions depended from the Ministry of the Interior, which was at that time an entirely native department, and not, strange to say, from the Ministry of Justice. The appointment of M Legrelle to the post of Public Prosecutor in 1887 marked the starting point of reform. He investigated the working of these speoial courts, and demnn^r vted the enormity of their abases, dnp to tin absence of European supervision.

In May, 1889, they were at last abolished. Although originally instituted for a fewmon4bs. the first short period had been prolonged by special d crees, until the oourts bad been in working for five years. The work for which they had been formed had been done by them, for in 1890 acts of brigandage were few and far between, although the means by which this end was attained were snoh as would not bear close investigation. But it was the abolition of these very courts which started the ill-feeling between Ri z Pasha, the Premier, and Sir Evelyn Baring ill-feeling which culminated in the appointment of Mr. Sjott as Jadioal Ad- vuer to the Egyptian Gjvemment and the re-igrutijn of R'sz.

Thus, if S r Edward Grey's threat of un­constitutional measures is to be oarried oat, there is a very good precedent for the insti­tution of a similar set of conrts for the re­pression of acts of assault. Only this time there will ba no abuses, for the jadioial system in Egypt has been regulated since the Com­mission of Brigandage, and every case will be thoroughly investigated—as all judgments are now—by the staff of European inspectors which iaat present attached to the Ministry of Jastioe.

div.head: THE DENISHWAI AFFAIR.
div.p: "Al Moayad" publishes the following re­marks on the Denishawi affair, the papers concerning which are to be submitted to the House of Commons to day ;—

The documents in regard to the Danishwai case have been translated and submitted to the British Government ; and the first day of Aagust is the date when those papers will be examined by Parliament. How will it end ? To this question the former measures taken by the British officials give the reply. The arrangements made by Lord Cromer and Sir Edward Grey will give a political colour to the papers, and produce an excuse strong enough to let the British officials in Egypt esoape from any blame or responsibility for the acts they oommitted in the Denishwai affair The Mex affray and the aggression on Mr. Ashton, the British inspector of irrigation, may be added to the Denish­wai outrage to emphasise the "dangerous fanaticism" which has been declared by Sir E. Grey in the British Parliament. The Liberal members will, we presume, remain silent and then the documents will be put aside for ever. This isjtbe conclusion whioh, it is thought, will be arrived at to-morrow,"

div.head: THE BRITISH GARRISON. THE COST TO EGYPT.
div.p: The announcement that Mr. Runoiman made on Monday night in the House of Commons, to the effect that the future strength of the British foroe in Egypt is to be about 5,700 meD, will be received with general satisfaction among the European population in Egypt, but at the same time it may be doubted whether the inoreaee is not too small considering the actual condition of affairs, and that there would have been a greater sense of seourity if the dambers of the garrison had bsen nearer 10,000 than 5,COO. The native Press can have no valid grounds for complaint at the extra expense which Egypt will have to bear for maintaining an inoreased garrison, for that "he who calls the tone must pay the piper" is a principle of world wide application.

As there is a good deal of ignorance as to the exaot financial relations between the British and Egyptian Governments in regard to the Army of Occupation, the following aooount will not be inopportune at the present moment. In 1904 the.zimnual cost of the Army of Occupation to the Egyptian Government was inoreased from L.E. 84,825 to L.E. 97,500. The reasons for this increase were as follows : In the early days ot the Occupation, the yearly contribution of the Egyptian Treasury towards the expenses of the British garrison was a sum representing at the time the true extra cost of maintaining the then existing garri­son, over and above that which would have been incurred had the troops been stationed in the United Kingdom. For 1885, an ar­rangement was made ander which Egypt paid a sum of 4/. per head per month to­wards the expenses of the troops op to a maximum ot 200,000/. This arrangement remained in force for two years, after which the snm was reduoed to L.E. 84,825. At this figure, independently of extraordinary expenditure connected with military opera­tions in the Sadan, it was allowed to re­main until 1301, although it was far from representing the true extra cost of the gar­rison. Io the course of the summer of that year the matter was reconsidered, and the British Government, taking into considera­tion the improved financial condition of Egypt, expressed a desire to retain to the original agreement. It was impossible to contest so legitimate a dem tnd, bat in order that the fature charge should not weigh heavily on the Egyptian Treasury it was agreed that the namber of British troops permanently stationed in this country should be reduced, and the sum payable fixed at L E. 97,500 (100.O0G/.) a year, or an inorease of only L.E. 12,675. This sum, which was not to be liable to fluctuations arriving from any minor changes in the total cost of the garrison, represented approximately the true extra expenditure incurred by the British Government by reason of the presence ot a British foroe in Egypt, as constituted from the 1st January 1905. The reduction in the foroe (including the British troops at Khar­toum) was expected to bring the number of the garrison to about 3,500 men. Lord Cromer in his pennltimate R°pjrt remarked that it was not necessary nor desirable ' on Egyptian as on more general grounds, that the force should be large," and his Lordship added that "the reduced garrison will amply suffice as a guarantee for the maintenance of public order under all ordinary circumstances." The circumstances that have ensued in the eighteen months since these words were written have induced Lord Cromer to complete'y change his opinion.

Another credit has bean opened for erecting a landing stage on the Nile bank near Kasr el- Ali, Cairo.

div.head: EGYPT'S UNEMPLOYED.
div.p: To esoape the vigilance of the police a namber of Berbereen have fled to Ramleh and other suburbs, but the Gouveruorat has issued a circular tj the several kisms is order to apprehend the vagrants.

Passengers at Bab-el Hadid station, Cairo, were not a little surprised yesterday morning by the unwonted speotaole of aboot five score of these tramps, esoorted by shawishes, who were being sent off to their homes in the provinces.

Daring the last three days in Cairo alone upwards of three hundred of these idlers have beep arrested, and they inolnde a goodly number of Europeans who are being dealt with by their respective consulates. One of these undesirables bad been wanted for robbery, and had on his person the jewels he had stolen several months ago.
Expulsion in the oase of the Berbereen is impossible, as they all belong to tribes in Egypt
The penalty for vagrancy is two months*

div.head: THE NATIVE PRESS IN EGYPT. MUSTAPHA KAMEL'S ROLE.
div.p: The following suggestive letter appears in the "Standard" :

Sir,—The letter appearing in yonr issue of the 23rd ult. from Mustapha Pasha Kamel will he found instructive in England as an authoritative exposition of the views of the self-named National party in this country. That numerous portion of the home poblio which indulges in the belief that the Egyptians are grateful for the benefits arising to them from the British occupation will be surprised to learn that not only snoh is not the case, but that actaally the British are the subjects of their cordial detestation. This, however, is a truth to whioh, as an old resident in Egypt, I can confidently testify. Never, since 1882, do I remember a period when the people, both in town and country, were more antagonistic to us.

This result is unquestionably owing to Mus­tapha Pasha Kamel himself and his congeners of the pan-Islam Press, who, since the Akaba dispute, have (doubtless under orders from Yiidiz) persistently directed the anti European sentiment, always more or less current here, against the British. Without the pernicious teachings of that Press the peaceable and normally-phlegmatic Egyptian peasant would never have developed into the demoniac of Denishwai, ready to bludgeon, or even burn aVve, British officers in uniform, and that within six miles of their armed force of 150 men capable of scattering like ohaff before the wind the whole of the inhabitants of the village.

Daring last year's European naval demon­stration against *he Porte a belief was current amongst the low class native population of Alex­andria that an order from the Saltan might be daily excepted in Egypt to oommenoe the "Jehad,"or Holy War, and this oulminated in a riot on December 10,which might have resulted much more seriously than it aotually did. The popular sentiment was then unquestion­ably anti European, but, since Akaba it has been directed specially against the British, and the Denishwai outrage with its stern re­tribution has been one of the results. I regard the school of which Mastapha Pasha Kamel is the ohief as being the direct oaase of both these incidents.

When Mastapha Pasha Kamel affirms that "outsiders" have chiefly profited by British rule in Egypt, he makes a statement entirely ' contrary to fact, it being impossible to peruse any of Lord Cromer's reports without perceiv­ing the exclusive way in which all his efforts have been directed to the good of Egypt and the Egyptians. To the Egyptian peasant—the bulk of the population—the British occupation has been salvation; others, if profiting, have done so hut incidentally.

In my view, the proper recognition of the oontents of the letter of Mustapha Pasha Kamel would be the prompt abandonment by us in Egypt of our blameworthy latitude in Press matters, so astonishing to all the foreign colonists there resident, and the cutting off of the stream of perennial poison with which the pan-Islam journals now so disastrously flood the country. I know that in England the "liberty of the Press" is a maxim of almost idolatrous worship, and any proposed restraint in this respect is looked at askanoe. The advantages arising from the liberty of the press as from other forms of liberty depend maoh upon the education and capacity of the receiver. Actually, in Egypt, a country emerging from a serfdom of centuries, snoh liberty in the hands of writers of the type of Mnstapa Pasha Kamel and his colleagues is a source ot great danger to the whole commun­ity, whether native or foreign—henoe th:s letter. - I am, Sir, your obedient servant,
A Sincere Friend of the
Egyptian People.
Cairo, Jaly 9.

div.head: PROTECTION OF FRENCH SCHOOLS.
div.p: The Franoiscan Sisters recently decided, without awaiting the solution of the question of the Protectorate of the Latin Patriarchate of Jerusalem, to transfer their schools at Kasr el Niland Clot Bey from French to Italian protection by placing them under the patronage of the Italian National Association for Eastern Missions, which has undertaken to pay the annual subsidy of 6,000 franos, till then pay­able by the Propagation of the Faith of Lyons, a French institution. In addition to this, the Italian Ministry for Foreign Affairs has grant­ed the schools a subsidy whioh, together with the 6,000 frano% will guarantee the existence of these schools.

div.head: THE BOUNDARY COMMISSION-
div.p: (From our Correspondent.)
Pers, July 23.

The arrival of the Turco-Egyptian boundary commissioners at El ArUh, in Egyptian terri tory, is officially announced. As yonr readeri are aware, the Turkish commission refused at first to go to El Arish, and its arrival in that locality is considered here as a diplomatic 8000698 for the Egyptians. The first pour parlers, howsver, gave rise to such divergen cies of opinion that negotiations have been suspended in order to draw up a new plan of discussion.

Relations between the Patriarchate ot Alexandria and the ArchbishopolMoant Sinai are, aooording to a Gresk contemporary, somewhat straired. They were never very oordiat,Kat lately they have become bitter over the question of the sohool founded in 1861 by the brothers Raphael and Anania Ampetion, for poor children of the Greek community According to the will of the founders, the school was to be placed under the control o a committee of nine, whose president was by right to be the Archbishop of Moant Sinai. 11 now appears that the Arohbishop wished tc prohibit certain persons not possessing the confidence of the community from joining the board of the sohool. Regrettable inoidenti ensued,and the Patriarchate of Alexandria hac to interfere. Monsignor Photius asked the Archbishop of Mount Sinai bis reasons for excluding these persons, and why he had gone to Cairo without the authorisation of hii hierarchical ohief. The Arohbishop vouohsafec no reply and henoe a conflict has sprung up between the Churohes of Jerusalem and Alex andria.

div.head:
RUSSIAN CRISIS.
MUTINY OF TROOPS
LOCAL INFANTRY BOMBARDED
500 KILLED OR WOUNDED.

div.p: ' The garrison of the artillery fortress of Sveaborg mutinied last night and bombarded the quarters of the loyal infantry. 500 men were killed or wonnted. The troops of the garrison at Skatndden matinnd this miming and imprisoned their officers. (Reuter)
The artillery in the Sveaborg fntress
mntinied. The iufantry remained faithful, and a oonfliot took place, in the coarse of which 500 men were killed or wounded. The mutineers occapy three islands. (Hxon)
All the revolutionary organisations, includ­

ing the ex uiembera of the Duma, have issued a manifesto to the peasants urging them to seize the land of which they had been deprived by the diabolical designs of the Grand Dukes and other counsellors of the Tsar, and to remove the local authorities and select their own representatives instead. The Government had declared war on the nation and now was the time for the country to rise.
The Government ha9 decided to prosecute the signatories of the Viborg manifesto.

The gravity of this mutiny will be appreciat­ed by everyone who has any acquaintance with the capital of Finland, for Sveaborg is one of the stock excursions from Helsingfors, from which it is only half an hour's trip in a steam­er. Sveaborg has been called the "Gibraltar of the North" and is of enormous strategic im portanoe, for it proteots the naval harbour of Heisingfors, which is the most important naval station of the Russian Baltic fleet after Cron stadt. The entrance to the harbour is secured by a ohain of seven or eight small islands three of which have been oocupied by the mu­tineers, and the defence? of which are called the fortifications of Sveaborg.

There is only one entrance by which large ships can reach the harbour; shoals or dams from one island to another blocking up all the other passages. The immediate entrance lies between the islands of Lmgern (whioh i9 200 yards from the southern extremity of the town) and Vester-Svert, and is about 200 yards across ; it is commanded by the fire from the two islands, besides being raked by the batteries on the Oster Lilya-Svert, which lies south of the opening between the two former. These three northern fortresses not only defend the ohannel, but also command points on the mainland, where an enemy after takirg the town might attempt to plant his batteries. Three other islands to the southward (Vargen, Gustav Svert, and Oster-Stuor Srert), similarly situated, and if possib'e still more strongly defended, oommand the entranoe from the Gulf, the whole front presented by the succes­sive works being abiut a mile in length. The fortifications on these grunite rooks are suid to be of the mo?t formidable description: the ramparts are scarped out of the rock itself; the batteries are armed with the heaviest ordnance; and each series of works has its own stores of all kinds and bomb-proof cove'*. Casern utes are formed for 6,0.0 or 7,000 small arms, and the united fortresses are said to mount 900 cannon and to be garrisoned by 12,000 men ; and there are magazines, arsenal*, and barrack? both upon one of the islands (Gustav Svert) and upon the mainland.

The serioas natare of the outbreak is apparent, and if the mutinous troops can hold the fortifications of Sveaborg, not only the Finnish capital, but the whole of the Grand Dnchy, may raise the flag of revolt.

div.head:
ARMENIANS AND TARTARS.

div.p: A regular campaign between Armenians and Tartars, lasting a waek, has taken p'aoe. The Tartars attacked Askeran pass, which was held by Armenians, and were repulsed. The sarroanding villages are the scenes of carnage. The town of Shosha is in ll ime?, having been subjected to a five days' fasillade. ( Renter)

div.head: NAVY REDUCTION
div.p: GOVERNMENT CENSURED
LOCAL INFANTRY BOMBARDED
London, July 31.

House of Lords —An interesting debate took place on the question if the redaction of the naval programme. Lord Cawdor censored the Government's departure f orn the original scheme and said they were seating up an evil precedent. Lord Camperdown ridiculed the idea that the reduction? woald have an influence on the programme of foreign nations.
Lord Tweedmontb admitted that the Go vernment had put before the Sea Lords the desirability of reducing the Estimates.

Lord Goschen insisted that Germany was bent upon an imperial policy, and that anyone who hoped that the resolutions passed at the Hague Conference woald be likely to arrest what she considered to be her mission, namely, to expand her power, was in a fool's paradise.
(lteuter)

div.head: DREADNOUGHT SQUADRON.
div.p: WORLD'S SWIFTEST BATTLE FORCE.

The statement published in the "Daily Tele­graph" to the effect that in place of two Dreadnoaghts andtwubig armoured cruisers— the original shipbuilding programme for this year—the British Government, as a result of a compromise with theBoardof Admiralty,intend to build three Dreadnoaghts, is authoritatively confirmed. These ships will be laid down at an early date, one being constructed at Ports­mouth, another at Devonport, and a third by a private shipbuilding firm. By the end of the year after next the British Fleet will thas obtain, with the vessel now completing at Portsmouth, a homogeneous strategical unit of four of these powerfol mon-of war, mounting forty gans of the new 12in. type, throwing ai> 850 b shell, and 108 12-pounder anti torpedo- boat weapon0, with a very rapid fire.

The squadron of Dreadnoughts will have a sea speed of twenty-one knots, and will be able to cross the Atlantic and return with ont re coaling, so ample will be the provision of coal and oil fuel. These ships will draw less water than any battleship bnilt in recent years and will be admirably suited either for service in the shallow waters of the North Sea or for use east of Suez, as they are well propor­tioned for passing throngh the Canal. In spite of their great displacement, 17,900 tons, the D eadnonght? will require 18in. less water for navigation than the 15,000-fcon battleships of the Queen, Bulwark, and Formidable types, and will have the advantages of three knots in speed, while they will maik a gain of 42in in draught over the Majestic olass, of which one, ths Victorious, it will be remembered stnok for some time off Port Said wheu on her wiy to China. 1 base fonr Dresdnonghts, on the other hand, will be the longest and broadest battleships hitherto built, and will form the swiftest and most pewerfni battle squadron in the world's fleets.

div.head: THE NILE
div.p: ITS PHYSIOGRAPHY

No river on the face of the globe has appeal- ed so long and so vividly to the human * imagination as the Nile. Its regular annual rise and fall, so unlike the random vagaries of * other streams, its indispensable and never failing maintenance of the soil and fertility 1 of Egypt in the midst of a surrounding de g sert, the persistent mystery in which it shrouded i s distant soarces (fontium gui celat origines Nilas') have afforded from re- ' mote antiquity subjects for vagne wonder- ment and crude speculation. Only within our 1 own time has the problem of the Nile been t solved, though even now it still presents aspects that will demand further exploration and study. The reader who, familiar only with the history of the problem as it appears in ancient literature, opens the large vo- j lume on the "Physiography of the; River Nile r and its Basin," which has been prepared by c Captain Lyons, Director of the Egyptian Sorvey Department, may be pardoned if he should receive a kind of shock when he turns Q over the crowded paragraphs of statistics, the repellent tables of measurements, the seemingly interminable diagrams of river-sec- 8 tions, and the serried array of dry facts which t follow each other through more than 400 a printed pages. His first feeling may, perhaps, be that he would rather have had the old q brooding mystery perpetuated for centuries to come than see it dissipated in this way by the ruthless and resistless methods of the j modern man of scienoe. There is certainly no poetry or romance in this voluminous report. And yet the story which it has to tell, stripped of its technical verbiage, is not without a kind of romantio interest. As by the labours of successive courageous ex­plorers the oortain has been raised behind which for so many centuries the secret of ® the great river lay hidden, and as the real j explanation has been revealed of the fea- tores that so long puzzled mankind, the old sensation of blank wonder is replaced by g one of keen appreciation of the simple and yet complex beauty of the phenomena. We j are made to confess that the actnal truth proves to be even more marvellous than g were the speculations of antiquity in search of it. The Nile is die covered to be no ab- normal stream, bat to show by the admira- b'y adjusted movements of the atmosphere y in its vast basin, by the mntoal relations^ between its huge lakes and the rivers flowing v out of them, by the grouping of its high lands and low plains, and by the remarkable q distribution of rainfall, that it furnishes a new and impressive illustration of the same laws j( which everywhere govern the circulation of 3 water over the face of the land. j
For mqre than 5 030 years the dwellers by | of the framework o{ Abyssinia that Egypt
the banks of the Nile have watched apd re­corded the annual rise and fall of the river on which they depended for most of the necesBa-

ties of life. In more recent years the same jn 8nspension by the Nile daring its coarse practical needs have given rise to the various throngh Egypt. The general results ot some gigantic engineering works that have been jDqaiIi03 made by the Survey under Captain ionstrooted for the greater util>z»t«on of the Lyong ate 8oppi;ed io the report, '['he water vater of the r.ver But besides meeting the of the Blne Nile at Khartoum was examined udustnal demands the authorities, during the ; w0ek, dQti 1902 a of 6xeeptionall British.occupation have found room for a ,Qw flood and tfae tion ofSQSpeDded ailt .oieotifio investigation of the country. They wftg fonnd tQ frQm a ffi0an of 3g in mve appropriately entrusted to heir lately-1 mUU dnri Dec()mb mean Q, 95g
Htabhahed Survey Depar meat the task of. in a millioD> doli August. Tbe ohe.
?a*h?ring together and co. lati ng the scattered I . ,° , ... , .
.? ■* r a ii j a, is. mical composition of the suspended silt and of
ibserva ions e rave ers an e resu s .b0mjneta| 00ntained insolutioniothe water of
.btainod by their own official staff w. h regard I Nj,e has bflen varioo8, determined b djf. :o the meteorology and hydrology of the whole ■ fer6nt ana.yjt8i and aome of tbeir,jeflnIt8 are

tmple Nile basin ; aad the outcome of this 1 alnar is the volame now bef ire us. The title )f the Report is perhaps rather ambitious, when so much of the physiography of the •egion '8 still unknown. The geology in parti- iolar has been most imperfectly explored. Bot is a contribution towards that fuller descrip­tion which will donbtlecs be furnished before nany years pass the volume mast t>»ke h'gh •auk. No snch c'eirly arranged and well rea- ioned accoaut of tin while sabj *ot has before seen attempted ; and no one could have been selected so well fitted as Captain Lyons to deal adequately with every branch of the wide range of inquiry involved.

The report discusses the climate, meteoro­logy and hydrology of i hi whole extensive region drained by the Nile, stretching 'nm the water shed of Lake Victoria on the south side of the equator throngh more than 30 deg. of latitude to the shores of the Mediterranean Sea. For oonvenieocs of treatmint this large part of Africa is grouped into separate basin'. Far to the south lie* tbeLakj Plateau Bisi.iunmpris ing the vast equatori 1 laka3. Farther north the Bihr el GhazU Basin on the west and the Sobat Basin on the east mingled their waters to form the White Nile. From the high tab'e- land of Abyssinia the drainage of the basins of the Blue Nile and the Atbara descends into the plains to unite with the White Nile in forming the great river of Egypt. The Nile below this junction is deec ibed in throe sec­tions—from Khartoum to Assoaan, from As­souan to Cairt, and from Cairo to the Medi­terranean. These several traots of country present some remarkable contrasts of climate. They include, on the one hind, hot, rainless plains, and on the other cod, moist plateaux surmounted by frost-bound mountain peaks. Of special importance in regard to the fl .w of the Nile is tin distribution of the rainfall. It will be remembered that, according to one of the ancient explanations, the annual flood of the liver arises from the melting of snows in Ethiopia. Herodotus forcibly argaed against thia view, and the objections to it were still more clearly urged by Seneca, who pointed in support of his argument to the proofs of the great heat of the climate cf Ethiopia as evin­ce d by the dark oolour of the inhabitants, by

the absence of lrbernating animals in the country, and by the presence of serpents even on the highest ground. We now know definite ly that the annual inundation is due to the copious rains that fall in certain parts of the Nile Basin. In Egypt and the greater part of the Sudan the yearly, amount of rain is so small as to be practically negligible. Upon the Abyssinian plateaa, on the other hand, it Bmonnts to probably not less than from 60 in. to 70 io. In the region of the equatorial lakes it appears to vary considerably, being in some plaoes only 30 in. or less, while in others it is 90 in. or mor\ The rain belt has its mean position about 1 deg. north of the equator, where there is almost constant preoipitation. As the belt moves northward with the summer it carries its moisture into the Southern Sudan and the basin of the White Nile and provides the copious downpour on Abyssinia.

The most important result of the modern study of the hydrology of the Nile is shown by Captain Lyons to be the discovery of the relative shares taken by the White and the Blae Nile in the supply of water to the main river. It has been ascertained that a praotically uniform supply is furnished by the vast reser­voirs of the equatorial lakes, so that the White Nile above its junction with the Sobat maintains all the year ronnd nearly the same constant volame. The variations in the rainfall from one season to another do not appear serioasly to modify this uniformity, so that the White Nile plays bat a feeble part in the annual rise of the river in Egypt, amounting perhaps to le-s than one twentieth of the flood. The most important influence affeoting this branch of the Nile is that of the Sobat river, which, descending from the Abyssinian high lands, is periodically swollen by the heavy rains ot that region, and when ponded back at high water by the flood in the Blue Nile pro­vide* a material increase m the volnme of the White Nile in mid-winter.

It is the contribution of the Bine Nile which gives to the Egyptian river its distin­guishing characteristics. In consequence of the copious rains that descend upon the Abyssinian tableland that tract of high land has been deeply trenched with innumerable gullies, ravines, and valleys, which have been cut out of the solid rocks by the streams that flow in them. From Jane to September these channels are filled with rushing muddy water, which sweeps its burden of sediment into the Bine Nile and the Athara, and thus supplies Egypt with its regularly recurring inundation and its annually renewed layer of silt. Few regions on the face of the globe illustrate more vividly than Abyssinia the extent to which a fence continuous tableland of solid durable volcanic rock may be carved by running water into an intricate system of gorges and valleys. The river Bashilo, near Magdala, flows at the bottom of a canon which it has eroded in the level sheets of basalt to a depth of more than 3 000ft., while the gorge of the Jitta river is still more profound. Thus it is at the expense
receives a constant increase to its fertile soil.
* Many observations and measurements have been made of the amount of sediment carried

tabulated in the present volume. The river has been flawing and depositing its annnal load of fine mud for so long a lapse of time that it has laid dowa upon the floor of its valley a deposit ranging from 30 to 80 feet in thickness. From observations of the rate which the deposit is thought to take place and measurements of the depth of alluvium, computations have been given of the time which has passed away since the river first began to fl iw. But the data on which snch estimates have been framed are hardly of such a trustworthy character as to warrant their acceptance. Th re cr, of course, l;e no doubt that the river is he'ghtening and broadei.iug its fbod plain, and at the same time rai-iug the level of its bed. The rate of rise ot the s. rface of the plain, odcnlated from the present position of the bipe : of ancient monuments now buried under tin accumulate! silt, hss been said to be be­tween 3| and 8 inches in a century. But the
ate is not everywhere uniform, 'there seems reason to believe that tin ii crease ia the heght of the tlo d plain is slightly more rapid thau that of the bed of the river.

The Egyptian Government under its British tutelage is much to le congratulated on having established a series cf scientific surveys where­by the geology, metereology, and hydrology of the country will be fully and accurately worked oat and the numerous laoumu in our knowledge of them, as revealed in this volnme, will be filled up. As an excellent instalment of wh it may be expected from the labours of these organizations the present volume by the Director of the Survey Department de­serves a hearty welcome. ("Times" Literary Supplement.)

div.head: PLEA FOR THE TURK
div.p: The following letter appears in the "Daily Mail"

Sir,—The anonymous letter which Lord Gromer gives as an example of the feeling exist­ing in Egypt against England, and which yon publish in Taesday'a "Daily Mail," illustrates the feeling of indignation that trembles in the breast of every subject of the Saltan who apprehends the fact that England has reonded on him, and has been so openly at cross-purpo­ses with the suzerain of Islam. Small wonder that his sense of justice is violated, when he finds his whilom friend ready to accept as gospel the inventions of interested fanatics anent Armenian and other "atrocities," without inquiring whether the so called "victim" was the placid angel he was sopposed to be, or whether he was not the more crafty ruffian and the more consummate hypoorite of the two.

Surely it speaks well for a nation which pro­vides an asylum for a despised and ontoast people of a different religion to itseh f Where are the Jews finding rest to day ? Where are the real atrocity victims of Holy Russia seeking a solace from their woes nut under the shelter of the Turkish Government ?

Is it right, sir, to insult through officialism the amonr propre of a great nation whose love of toleration oan give lessons of meroy and oharity both to Greek and Latin Chnrohes, as all denizens of the East fully know 1

Is it not time to call a halt to this folly, and to give this brother man a little fair play f Even if he be in error,he ii a man, and methinks we are not likely to influence him for good if we refase to recognise his sterling goods points. Lord Salisbury is dead ! Is wisdom dead with him ? John C. Taylor.
Harmondsworth Vicarage.
COLD STORAGE CURE.

The very latest thing in cures for hay fever is "cold-storage." It comes, as one might almost have guessed, from aoros9 the Atlantic. A gentleman who was a great victim to hay fever happened one summer to spend two hours in the refrigerating hold of a steamer. This cured him, and he had no farther at­tacks that summer. Thenceforward, whenever an attaok threatened, he beat a hasty retreat to a cold atorage ohamber, and was cured. The idea, says the "Hospital," is simple and pretty, but still in its infancy and awaiting judgment. It is quite likely to be as success­ful as other oures, with the single exception of a sea voyage. This our contemporary has never known to fail.>2
OUR COTTON INDUSTRY.
The Manchester oorrespondent of the ' Globe" says :—

The ontlook in oar staple trade is improved by the continuation of good rains in India.The crops in our dependency are now assured, for the ground will be prepared for seed. Though there is very little basiness going on in cotton piece goods, it is expected that in a month or so dealers in Bombay and Caleotta will begin to give out cloth orders to make. It must be stated, however, that stocks in the "godowns" in Bombay are heavy. Raw cotton prospects in America are again most encouraging, the weather in the States being all that could be desired. Egypt, too, is doing well. The crops in Pern and Brazil are likely to be larger than the current season. One thing seems pretty sore—that the snpply of raw material for next year is likely to be folly equal to the wants of the world.

div.head: FAMINE TOWN
div.p: JAGANIR, THE POVERTY STRICKEN.
BY AN EYE-WITNESS.

It lies in British India, forty miles from any­where, on a great tongue of barren land, that thrusts itself, parched and rugged, between two poverty stricken native States. It lies alone ; alone in its poverty, its dust, and its blazing sunshine ; alone with its starving inhabitant', and its bitter, parched fields ; alone with its desolate ravines, its brackish wells, and its ruined temples. When the famine began in Jaganir the inhabitants were driven to desperate straits to save their starv­ing oattle—for, without oattle, no well can be worked, and no water drawn to irrigate the little patches, that stand, in famine time, be­tween the native and complete starvation. But nor the oattle toil no more at the wells, for they are all dead, and the little patches of young oorn are withered and destroyed ; while in the desperate struggle to find fodder for their oattle, every tree over vast traots of country has been denuded of its foliage, and now the leafless trees stretch their gannt arms to a fiery sky—with fearful resemblance to the starving and plague-strioken people who matter and die beneath thee^

The mined houses and temples which form the town, enoirole a great mass of rook that rises a sheer 300 feet above it. This rook is orowned with an anoient fort, and with still more anoient temples, the summit being reach­ed from the town by a great flight of worn and sun-beaten steps, ont in the faoe of the rook and ornamented with carved arohways and porohes. The temples on the summit are Jain and BrahmiD, and the great red stone fort was raised by the mighty Mogul Emperor, Akbar the Wise. Bat all is now deoay and desolation. In equal ruin lie the carved wonders of Jain Priests and pions Brahmin, with the inlaid marbles and arabesques of the Mogul Em­perors. Here the only inhabitants are the mangy hysena and the fieroe panther, and, perhaps, some starving wretch, who having ex­hausted the generosity of his oaste-fellows, has orawled up from the rained town below to orouoh in some dark reoess, and to die — alone. It is but early Maroh, bat the heat is intense ; already the blazing son of an Indian summer beats down with a force that is not soon forgotten ; while from the son- beaten snrfaoe of the rock there seem? to leap the fiery breath of 1,000 years of fieroe snnshine and hot winds. Far down below the flat-topped roofs of the ruined houses shimmer and tremble in a haze of beat Away on all sides the horizon stretches like a petrified sea ; mile after mile of arid stony hills, and barren plains, aoro38 which smoking pillars of hot air and dnst whirl in a mad danoe, mock­ing the empty fields and the withered trees ; while the whole landscape trembles in an into­lerable glare. Down in the narrow stone-paved streets of the town, miserable wretches who have never known the meaning of a good meal, matter aud stumble along, in dimless misery. The air here is like a furnace ; the minnte shops, little dark stone recesses blackened with the smoke and toil of centuries, are mostly good.

div.head: MR. OZIAL ROUNDS.
div.p: A Resident of Welland Finds Relief in Pe-ru-na.
SUFFERED 15 YEARS.
Mr. Ozial Hounds, Welland, Ont., a retired lumberman and a resident of We'lnnd for half a century, writes:
"For fifteen years prior to 1900 I was a sufferer from hay asthma and chronic diarrhea. I grew weak and emaciated and was tortured with In­somnia.
"I was treated by eminent physicians but, if anything, was worse than ever. In fact, I was in as miserable a condi­tion as a man could be.

"However, / chanced to try Peruna and noticed an Improvement. Thus encouraged, / continued, and after tak­ing several bottles of your precious Peruna, I was entirely well aud a wonder to myself and friends.

"If, at my advanced age, 88 years, I have obtained such good results from Peruna, after so many years of needless suffering, there can be no doubt of its efficacy in the treatment of younger persons."

div.head: MARSEILLE EN 1905.
div.p: Le service da port de Marseille, soas la di­rection da commandant Gappeter, vient de publier la Statistique de l'année 1905, faisant connaître le mouvement général de la naviga­tion et da trafic, avec ses éléments constitutifs, oomparé à celai de l'exercice précédent.

Pendant l'année éconlée, le mouvement ma­ritime total du port de Marseille, entrées et sorties réanies, s'est élevée à 16 882 navires, aveo 15.623.COO tonneaux de jaage nette et 6,215,000 tonnes de marchandises, portant 398,0C0 passagers et 560,000 hommes d'é- quipage.
Par rapport à 1904, ces chiffres sont en augmentation de 992 navires, de 2,270,000 tonneaux de jauge, et 362,000 tonnes de mar chandises, de 66,000 passagers et 67,000 hommes d'^qaipage.

La statistique du port en 1905 renferme une foule d'autres indications précieuses. C'est ains' qne la répartition da tonnage de jau­ge, entre les principaux pavillons, attribue 7,866,000 tonneaux à la France, 3,966,000 toDneaax à l'Angleterre, 887,000 tonneaux à l'Italie, 766,000 tonneauxàl'Allemagne,620,000 tonneaux à l'Espagne, 483,(00 tonneaux à l'Antriohe-Hongrie, 415,000 tonneaux à la Hollande et 380,000 tonneaox à la Grèce. De tous les pavillons, l'allemand est celui qui a relativement le plus progressé dans ces der­niers temps ■ il n'était représenté en 1900 que par 171,000 tonneaux.

Dans Ue chiffre total de* importations de* marchandises, qui égale 3,879,000 tonne?, les houilles étrangères figurent pour 890,000 ton ne\ Le total des exportations,évalué à 2.367,000 tonnes, ne comprend pas les charbons, vivres et autres approvisionnements de navires, soit 575,000 tonnes, ce qui élève à 2,941,000 tonne* le chiffre global des sorties et à 6,820,000 ton­ne* le mouvement général du trafic.

Le tonnage de jauge total, entrées et sortie' réunies, se répartit en 71,5% pour la navi­gation de concurrence et eu 28,5 % pour le cabotage réservé au pavillon national. Dans l'ensemble, le pavillon français et le pavillon étranger se partagent par moitié le tonnage de jauge. La navigation a vapear absorbe 95 % du mouvement maritime. Ces chiffres s'ap pliquent aux navires chargés, auxquels il y h lieu d'ajouter 10% du tonnage de jauge du port, concernant les navires sur lest.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny NOTES ET CRITIQUES.
div.p: Le Caire, Mardi 31 Juillet 1906.
Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres a été réduit hier de 1/8 à 3 1/8 pour cent.

Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais est resté invarié à 87 3/4. L'Unifiée a baissé de 1/4 de livre à 104 1/2. La National Bank est demeurée inchangée à 25 1/4, de même que l'Agricole à 9 5/8 et la Daïra à 16 7/8. Li Delta Light a perdo 1/^ à 11 1/2.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a olôtaré eu hausse de 5 francs à 760. La Banque
d'Athènes est restée stationnûre à 148.

Notre marché des valeurs a été loin de pré­senter, oe matin, la même animation qu'hier. Les traits caractéristiques de la séanoe ont été le calme et l'abstention. Néanmoins, les cours ont été bien défendas, et divers titres ont même obtena une plas-value. Nous traversons visiblement ane phase d'expectative, dont l'issue est sujette aux éventualités qui pour­raient se produire en Rassie et surtout aux effets que celles-ci détermineraient sur le* marché* financiers dirigeants.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National s'est maintenue à 25 7/16. L'Agricole s'e*t raffermie à 9 5/8-11/16. L'action nouvelle de la Cassa di Soonto a avancé à 213 ; l'anoienne est restée à 221-222. L* Banque d'Orient a faibli à 133 134 Le Comptoir Financier a été poussé à 6 1/4-5/16 l'action ancienne et 6 1/8 la nouvelle. La Banqae d'Abyssinie a atteint £ 6.
La Béhéra a avancé à 36-36 1/4. La Delta Light s'est consolidée à 11 7/8.

L'action Immobilière a avanoé à 368-370 ; la part de fondateur a gagné 15 francs à 670. L'action Enterprise and Development est reve nue à 12 1/8. L'action Agricole da Nil a fait 270. La Nile Land a progressé à 13 1/8. L'action AUotment a été moins bien tenue à
L38 Jouissances Eaux da Caire ont faibli à 261 1/2. La Frigorifiqae a été négociée à
Les Héliopolis out été ooté* 286-2o7 ; la part de fondateur à 8 1/4.
Rien de particulier à relever dans le groupe des valears hôtelières.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont clôturé à 3 3/8, le* Estâtes à 1 3/4, le* Sait and Soda à 20 sh. 6 et les Cotton Mills eatre 5 sh. 9 et 6 sh.

Suivant des informations de Bruxelles, le mouvement de haassa qui s'est produit subite­ment, la semaine dernière, sur les parts de fon­dateur de la Compagnie Immobilière d'Egypte a été déterminé par la propagation d'une rameur suivant laquelle la mise en liquidation de la Société aurait été décidée en prinoipb.
Il va de soi que cette nouvelle n'a reçu aucune espèce de confirmation.
Noas détachons d'ane lettre de Paris, en date du 24 Jaillet, les ligues suivantes :

"Bien quelle fût appréhendée depaiaquel­que temps, la dissolation de la Dqama a pro­duit ioi une impression des plus fâcheuses, et il est difficile de prévoir qaela nouveaux évé­nements elle nous prépare. Elle constitue, en tont cas, un retour offenstf du pouvoir autocrate et ne présage rien de bon pour l'avenir. Dans ces conditions, la baisse des fonds russes n'a rien que de bien naturel, et oe n'est pas impunément que notre marché supporte le poids énorme d'une quinzaine de milliards de valeurs portant cette étiquette.

" Le plus maltraité et le plus visé de tous les fonds russe* a été le nouvel emprunt de 1906. U est vrai qu'il est moins bien classé que les autres : un grand nombre de porteurs s'étaient empressés de passer la main lorsque le nouvel emprunt oota, au début, une prime de plusieurs points sur le coars d'émission. De là s'e*t créé un fi jttant q ri ne fait qu'augmenter par saite des ventes que provoqae l'approohe du 1er Août, date à laquelle doit se faire un'
versement de 20 % sar le titre non libéré."

Uu avii d* l'Egyptian Trust and Investment Ltd. (G ymeuopoulo) porte que, conformément à la résolation votée défiaitivement par l'as semblée extraordinaire des actionnaires tenue à Londres le 12 Juillet courant, M. George Thomas Broadbridge a été nommé liquidateur de la Société, avec une rétribution de £ 210, les frais non compris.
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

Les porteurs d'obligations hypothécaires 6 %, émission 1901, de la Crown Brewery of Alexandria sont informés qae le coupon No. 11 sera mis en paiement, à partir du 1er A ût proobain.à la Barq e Impériale Ottomane.

Les porteurs d'obligations hypothécaires 6%, émisssion 1902, de la Boulangerie Mécanique Hygién'que d'Egype, en liquidation, sont avisé* que le coupon N° 4, à détacher de ces titres, leur sera payé à la Barque Impériale Ottomane à Alexandrie, à partir du 1er Août prochain,

div.head: PITH OF THE PRESS.
Till'. TSAR'S LAST CARD.
div.p: The first Russian Parliament has been brought abruptly to an end. History already has to record numerous instances of blindness and provocation on the part of the Tsar's advisers, but it may be doubted whether any r-f them have been more momentons, more fraught with ruinous oonsequenoes, than his decision to dissolve the Duma.

The Government's arbitrary step, indeed, justifies only too complete'}' those Russian reformers who besought the friends of constitu­tional liberty in 'he West not to lond more money to the autocraoy. The event shows how little confidence can be placed in the secarity of Russian parliamentary institutions. The Russian Government obtained their loan, by what now looks uncommonly like false pre­tences, bat they cannot live on it for ever. The fnture is dark indeed for them and for the Empire, if they persist in their present policy. With a depleted exchequer and a disaffected army, how can they hope to hold down for ever an exasperated people, welded by their fatnoos shortsightedness into a strength and unity of purpose that it has never known before 1 ("Times".)
An International Peril.

Since the days when the development of the French Revolution compelled the inter­vention of the neighbouring Powers—an event which seemed as remote in 1789 as its repeti­tion appears improbable now—there has been no moment charged with a heavier anxiety for the general interests of mankind. An­archy in France wrapped the Continent and this coantry in the flame of war, which lasted, with interruption, for a quarter of a century, until peace had well-nigh disappeared from the memory of nations. Instead of indulging in irresponsible emotionalism, as did Fox and the English Whigs after the fall of the Bas­tille, with respect to the events that were happening across the Channel, let ns remember that the Tsar's re Urn is in the throes of a no less mighty travail, which may involve (qually stupendous consequences for good or ill, not only to Europe at large, bat to every people vhose interests are directly or indirectly oon- leoted with those of Russia, from the English channel to the Yellow Sea, and from the coast if Kent to the shores of Japan. ("Telegraph.") Russian's Credit Gone.

There is no disguising the fact that th^ lismissal of tin Duma is an act of war against he democracy, and the most probable result vill be to drive all the moderate Reformers into he arms of the Revolutionaries. We hear of a general strike in preparation throughout the jreat cities of the Empire. Even if the disastrous ixpedient should break down, it will suffice to damage Russian credit, and make borrowing impossible on the foreign bourses. Without ready money, and plenty of it, the Government will be unable to pay its soldiers and its police, ind without the mailed fist the bureaucracy nust capitulate at discretion. The last great tdvance from E iropean lenders was obtained )n the faith of agenaine Constitutional system )eing inaugurated. When the next application s made the men with money to invest will hold ;heir hands, because they will have no confi- lence in a Government which has broken faith with its former creditors. (' Standaid".)
Nicholas. Peacemaker.

We are unable to see the fitness of the pre- lent moment for paying compliments to the Emperor of Russia as an apostle of peace, as ve fail to see the wisdom of choosing this par- ioular time for disarming the British nation. To our terrestrial mind right comes before peace. Such rights as Englishmen have, have been won becaase Englishmen have been ready to shed their blood in asserting them and sach rights as Great Britain possesses have been won by freely spilling British blood by sea and land whenever there was a British right to ba upheld. With. Russia in the throes )f such a tumult as has not been seen in Sarope for a century there are many rights that nay be called in question, and the experience )t past convulsions of the same natare shows hat at such times wars are apt to spring up xmtrary to expectation. ( 'Morning Post"). French Criticism,

The most obvions feature of the situation is ;bat the Tsar and the revolutionaries neglect, n a cavalier fashion equally regrettable in bo'h, he obligations of Ru8.s:a towards foreign ooun- ries. If we Frenchmen indulge io follies, that s our own affair as we are our own creditors ; )ut Russia's creditors are to be found abroad— n Paris, and above all in Berlin (sic). What we laid was neither reaction nor revolution. We inggested progressive development through the formation of a constitutional Ministry responsi­ble to the National Assembly.The Tsar's reply to us is the dissolution of the Duma, the sup­pression of freedom of the Press and of liberty /speech, and a Cossack dictatorship. On the )ther hand, the revolutionaries—insurgents vith the temperament of drunken slaves— tssassius about whom one still hesitates to nake up one's mind as to who^e servants they ire—badly conceal their design of defrauding md ruining the holders of Ras3ian securities by mendacious phrases as to our pretended ack of Liberalism, although there is not a nogle Frenchman who does not ardently desire he transformation of Raesia into a Monarchy bn the English model. All this is monstrous.
Republique Framjaise''.)
Mr. Belt's Modesty.

First Cecil Rhodes ' Now Alfred Beit! Both aie names which will endure as praetorian in the story of the industrial, political, and geo graphical expansion of British South Africa. What each owed to the other for the fulfilment

of ideas is not to be apprised to-day. It is the work of ilia historian. He will find ample material. Cecil Rhodes was ever ready to say how greatly he was helped in his schemes of empire by Alfred Beit, who, on his part, was glad to work with his friend without sharing the platform of publicity. Modesty was a lead irg feature of A'fred Beit's disposition. It was only 0De, for kiudness which found expression in an exquisite regard for the feelings of others when doing a gcoi or charitable act was a leading characteristic of his natare Nothing came to him more natarady. It was part of the man. ("Ahican World.")
Cecil Rhodes as "Crank."

Mr. Beit's bequest of a million and a quarter for the construction of the Cape to Cairo railway recalls the fact that the late Cecil Rhodes was once considered a crank. The story was told not long ago by an old member of the Cape Parliament at a meeting at the Royal Colonial Institute. When Mr. Rhodes made his first appearance in the Cape Parliament he coaid talk of nothing but his great idea of a trans continental railway, and with the aid of a specially prepared map ha sought to interest h's fellow members in the colossal scheme. Most of them thought him a bore, and some openly called him a crank. His dream is now materialising. Many of ns can remember when Wagner was cons'dered a crank also, and when his ftiusio was a stock subject cf ridicule in "Punch." A crank is a man ahead of his age. ("Daily Chroniole.")
MANCHURIA'S "OPEN DOOR."

As reported by the "Times" correspondent at Tokio, Viscount Hayashi enters indignant protest against those foreign suspicions of Japanese good faith which have lately made themselves heard. These libels attribute to the insular Government a treacherous design of keeping the commerce of Manchuria wholly for the profit of its subjects, and in proof of that prop«'8itioD, they point to the long delay in establishing the "open door" in the Southern province. Viscount Hayashi does not attempt to deny that considerable delay has occurred, or that some Japanese traders have taken advantage of the opportunity to smuggle goods into the interior. Bat abases of one sort or another are bound to happen at the conclusion of any big war, involving the employment of exceptionally large foroes. At the termination of hostilities between Japan and Russia, our gallant allies found themselves responsible for supplying a million and a quarter of their fellow-countrymen.combatants.and camp follow­ers, with the necessaries ot life. That was an obligation of humanity as well as of patriotism, and who will censure the Tokio Government for giving it the first place in their arrange­ments ? B it by accepting the onerous task, the Executive imposed on itself the duty of tempo­rarily monopolising all available transport, and it is only now that the strain is beginning to be lightened. As for the traders who are alleged to have done brisk trade with the Chinese in goods hall-marked for the use of the Japanese troops, it is to be feared that precisely the same charge might be advanced against "smart" dealers belonging to other nationalities. But it is full time for these oensorious bickerings to cease ; Viscount Hayashi undertakes that in about a couple of months the Manchurian door will be thrown open to all comers on equal conditions.
THE BAHR-EL GHAZAL.

The Congo State Government apparently waits to be "hurried up" before withdrawing its occupying forces from the Bahr el-Ghszal, in compliance with the Anglo Belgian Con­vention. By that arrangement, it was pro­vided that the evacuation should take place "as soon as possible," but although some month-i have elapsed since the signature of the Convention, the latest information goes to show that the Congolese troops have not badged an inch. While quite agreeing with Sir E. Grey that large allowance should be made for the diffi julty of communicating with sach a remote country, we cannot forget that the Congo State used very qaick dispatch when fint permitted to enter the province. The Foreign Offne usually so fl ora detriment, in such cases, whenever it intermits the appli­cation of pressure, for as soon as the atten­tion of Downing street is direoted elsewhere nothing is done. It was a mistake to have employed such a very elastic phrase as "as soon as possible ; " some definife date should have been fixed for withdrawing the five little garrisons from the province. So long as they remain in evidence,.the natives must be per­plexed as to the authority to which they owe allegiance. As they are somewhat lawleis people, it is not odd that they should be beginning to doubt wh ither they are not releas­ed from any such obligation.
