THE COST OF A YACHT.
ARMY AND NAVY.

Fifty years ago sailing yachts of from sixty to a hundred toifipVere much more namerous, and they were owned by yachtsmen who trea ted them much as they would a suit of clothes of which they w$re food, keeping them till they were positively out ot date or old, fitting them out year after year as a matter of course, and enjoying their cruising like sensible beings. These are the views of Mr. Clive Holland, in a beautifully illustrated artiole in the Summer (August) number of the "Pall Mall Magazine.''
From the tbirty-tonners of the days of King Charles II, to the floating palaces of five Hun­dred tons and upwards of the present time is indeed a transition. <

The family boat of from, say, fifty to eighty tons (which is happily not quite an extiuot type), either hired or owned, runs away with a far greater sum of money than the uninitiated would suppose daring the three or four months of the season. *Saoh a boat—of say ninety tons— will make a large hole in £600, even if sailed on economical lines, and with a orew no more that sufficient to handle her properly. The cost of provisions is a heavy item, and harbour does also entail a very considerable expenditure when one is ornising either in home or foreign waters. Should a yaohtsman's fancy turn toward steam and "speed," the ooal bill will, in the case of a three-hnndred-tonner, probably monnt up to some £25 or £30 per week, or even more under exceptional cironm stances; and although there will be fewer hands than on a sailing yacht of similar tonnage, ooaling labour and other incidentals may be set off as against the reduced wages bill.

The cost of a fall season's "pot hunting" may be roughly estimated as £1,000 for the equivalent of the old forty rater, which sum affords a fairly accurate gauge if reduoed or increased as the boat may be smaller or larger.

In the case of the very well known oraoks, past and present, such as Ailsa, Bona, Britannia, Meteor, Shamrock, Luoida, and other similar oraft, probably a thoroughgoing season of thirty or forty starts will stand their owners in from £3,500 to £5,000, which latter sum will be greatly increased by competing in the earlier part of the year in Mediterranean water?, or by the yaoht in question being sent across the Atlantic.

Few summer holidays, indeed, if the weather be fine, are pleasanter than tho33 spent on an old, roomy, but seaworthy, yaoht of the past generation, of say twenty to forty tons, with a handy mar, and the crew formed of oneself and sea-loving friends. The cost of running each a boatfor twomonths in the summer has, of ocurse, no relation as regards expense to the sum required successfully to fit out and maintaia a modern yacht and its attendant luxuries such as we have described. A rough estimate based upon personal experience would put the hire of such a boat as we have described at from £5 tc £6 per week—wh:cb, supposing she be taken for six weeks, will amount to from £30 to £36. The wages of a thoroughly competent hand, iu fact a "handy" man capable of acting as captaio, steward, and cook, will not be mach less thaa 35'. a week—that is to say £10 10i. for the six weeks. A boy is al­ways useful and as appetities have a habit of sharpening up, it woald be unsafe to put down a less sum than 15s. a week per head for ordinary board, exclusive of any speoial luxaries, and, of course, of wines and spirits. Probably odds and ends in the way of tips when in harbour, harbour dues, and incidentals which are inseparable from a yachting cruise, will amount to another £2 per week ; but this item is one of the most variable, and it »s im­possible to make an estimate with ary exactitude.

Totalled up, the cost of a six weeks' oruise, for a party consisting of four friends, the owner, man, and boy, will amount to about £100, which split ap into five shares amongst the owner and his friends, amounts to £20 apiece. Patting it at £25, to provide for emergencies, it cannot be called a dear holi­day ; but it, of course, means that a good part of the work must be done by the holiday­makers themselves, and a certain amount of care and eoonomy exercised all round.
THE KING'S DONKEY-
AMUSING STORY OF MISUNDER­STOOD SIGNAL.

Some time ago King Edward sent a don­key as a present to his little grand on, Grown Prince Olaf of Norway. The don­key was carried by the steamer Montebello and the oaptain got instructions to lo:k well after the animal.

On arrival outside the Christiania fjord the captain signalled to the lighthouse "All right," but received no signal in reply. He then gave orders to signal "Ass" on one mast and "all right" on the other, but still no reply oame.
As it is a very important matter that the signals from vessels passing the light­house should be properly reported, the oap- taiu complained to the authorities.

The official explanation, says a Christiania correspondent, is this. At the moment the Montebello passed the light house the signal­man on duty was called to the telephone, and consequently oould not reply immediately. After having finished the conversation on the telephone, he saw the second signal flying— "Ass! ' "All right,"—and taking it as a personal snob, did not think it necessary to report it.
Because the representative of the Egyptian fellaheen now in London is oalled Kamel Pasha, it does not follow that he has got the hump,
(From our Correspondent.)
London, July 21.

Mijor V. S. Sandeman, 6th (Inniskilling) Dragoons, has gone on retired pay. He received his commission originally in the 17th Lancers in November, 1886, was promoted captain in 1896, whilst adjutant of the regiment, and was specially promoted major 1903, and trans­ferred to the 6th Inniskillings last October, as second in command. Msjor Sandeman served with the i 7 th Lanoers through the Boer War of 1899 '901, and shared in the operations in Orange River Colony, the Transvaal, Cape Colony and Orange Fiee State, and was se verely wounded in action (mentioned in des­patches, brevet majority, Queen's medal with five clasps).

Captain T.E. Bayley, 20thHussars, Brighton, has severed h:s connection with that regiment after serving over twelve years in it. He was appointed to it in January, 1894, got his troop iu 1899, and up till recently was a staff oap­tain at Cairo. His active service experience extended to the Tirah Expedition, 1897-98, in which he aoted as Assistant Transport Officer to the 3rd Brigade (medal with two olasps), and the Sooth African War, 1901-02, including the operations iu the Transvaal, Orange River Colony (Qaeen's medal with four clasps).

Major and Brevet Lieutenant Colonel G.T. Forestier-Walker has been transferred from the oommand of No. 5 Depot Royal Field Artillery, Clonmel, to the 122nd Battery R.F.A. Bulford, on completing the usual tour, with eff :ct from the 5th prox.

On the 5th piox., Lieatenant J. R. Bassett, 2ud Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment, Khartoum, will vacate the adjntanoy, and four days later Captain A. G. Macdonald will vacate the adjutancy of the 1st Battalion at Dublin.

The unpopularity of the "Broderick" oap is so great that the Army Coancil has again found it necessary to isaae a special order against the wearing of obsolete pattern oaps when soldiers, particularly those of the mounted service, are home on leave. The old "pill box" is still the favourite amongst the cavalry men. It seems a great pity that the oracs stupidity of the powers that be will not permit of Tommy Atkins wearing the smart looking ' pill-box" and the late field service oap in preference to the hideous and detested "Broderick," which has not a single redeeming feature.

The peace-at any-prioe shufflers of the British Cabinet have gone down before the determined attitude of the few men who put the Empire's interest before party, backed ap by the Admiralty officials responsible for the naval defence of the country. No thanks to the Little Englanders, the policy of "Britannia rules the Waves" is to be oarried out, and the first line of defence is to be kept ap to the usual standard of going anywhere, and doing aDythmg. The three Dreadnoughts originally proj -cted by the late Conservative Government, inclusive of the Dreadnought just launched, will be built, and the other departments of the navy will be kept in an efficient state. Men of the type of Sir Edward Grey are badly wanted in Campbell-Bannerman's collection of fad­dists. Sir John Fisher has had a lot to do with the continuance of the late Government's naval policy. "Jacky Fisher" is a hard man to beat, and the Empire'^ interests are safe so long as he is at the head of naval affairs.
AUSTRALIAN MAILS.
THE NEW SYNDICATE.

A cable from Sydney, published by the ' Shipping Gazette," discloses apiece of infor­mation which has been eagerly awaited iu the shipbuilding and shipowuing world. It is as to the constitution of the syndicate which has secured the contract with the Commonwealth Government for a fortnightly mail service between Australia and Great Britain, in sub­stitution for that of the Orient and Royal Mail Companies, which expires on Jan. 31, 1908. The names of the syndicate are given as follows.
1.Messrs. William Boardmore and Sons, ship builders, Dalmuir, N.B.
2.Messrs. Vickers Sons, and Maxim (Limited), Barrow-in-Furnesp.
3.Sir James Laing an I Sons (Limited), ship-builders, Sanderland.

4.Lord Armstrong, who, it may be inferred, represents Messrs. Armstrong Whitworth, and Co. (Limited), which firm, it may be definitely stated, has an interest in the shipbuilding policy of the syndicate.
5.A leading firm of shipowners in Great Britain, closely connected with the Australian trade, wh )se name is not at present disclosed.

It is evident from the names ab >ve given that the new enterprise ha9 fallen into powerfal hands, for the shipbuilding firms mentioned inolude some of the most distinguished in Great Britaiu The announcement comes at an opportune moment, for the delay in the formal intimation of the Commonwealth Premier—a delay entirely due to the pressure of other Parliamentary business—had given rise to various rumours in Australia. In London, too, there were those who were inolined to throw doubt on the undertaking into which it had entered. All suoh suggestions are now once and for all disposed of.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life.
